activity_b.text: What’s the required width of this access platform? It is 666 cm. But this access platform is only 575 cm wide at the moment. This access platform is 91 cm too narrow for safe movement.

activity_b.text: Yesterday was honestly hectic in the ICT lab.
We set up a complete computer network for the new training block near the library.
It’s definitely not a small setup.
It’s a full lab with thirty workstations, network switches, and a server cabinet, all running together.
The work was demanding, but the system is stable now, and that’s what matters.
Everyone felt the pressure, but we got through it.
So, how did you feel doing your first proper network installation?
Honestly, it was more complicated than I expected.
There are so many steps, and everything depends on the previous one.
First, the network diagram wasn’t very clear, so that was confusing.
Then some cables were too short, and a few ports weren’t active.
The router settings were correct later, but in the morning  the initial configuration was wrong.
The server rack was really heavy and awkward to position.
I mounted the main switch, connected the patch panel, and labelled the Ethernet cables.
A few labels were missing, so that caused a few issues.
Some PCs weren’t detected at the start, and that slowed down the whole process.
Yes, planning  is really everything in ICT work.
If the configuration is wrong, the entire network becomes unstable.
The IP addressing was mostly fine, but one subnet was slightly off.
That wasn’t ideal, but it was fixable.
The server is active now, and the access points are placed where they should be.
I agree.
Once the systems came online, the lab felt tense.
The checks were thorough, and everyone stayed focused.
We all knew that there was no room for careless mistakes.
After the final tests, everything was running smoothly.
The internet speed is stable, and everyone can access the printers.
Not every connection was perfect, but the system meets the requirements.
By the end of the day, we were exhausted but satisfied.
Today, the lab is much quieter.
There’s no installation work going on.
We’re checking logs and updating software only.
Next week, you’re going to configure user accounts and security settings.
Sounds good.
Next time, we’re going to prepare better.
Now we know what works, what fails, and how to sort out problems faster.
